I can see you have a failing test in your audio asset loader. The test expects a "Timeout" error but is getting a "Network error" instead. Let me examine the test file to understand what's happening.

asset-loader.ts
I can see the issue! In the loadAudioFile method, when the timeout occurs, the error message includes the timeout duration and URL, but the test is only checking for the word "Timeout". Let me look at the specific timeout error message:

The timeout error is: Timeout loading ${url} after ${this.options.timeout}ms

But the test expects just "Timeout". However, there's another issue - the fetch is being mocked to return a promise that resolves after 200ms, but the AbortController timeout logic might not be working as expected in the test environment.

Let me fix the test to properly handle the timeout scenario:

Accepted edits to

asset-loader.test.ts


The issue was that the test was using a promise that eventually resolves (after 200ms), but the AbortController in the implementation would abort the fetch before it could complete. However, the mock wasn't properly simulating the AbortController behavior.

By changing the mock to return a promise that never resolves (new Promise(() => {})), we're simulating a truly hanging request that will trigger the timeout mechanism. I also updated the assertion to use a regex pattern that matches the actual error message format: "Timeout loading [url] after [timeout]ms".

Excellent! All tests are consistently passing. Let me provide a summary of what I fixed:

Summary
I successfully fixed the failing timeout test in the AssetLoader unit tests. Here's what was wrong and how I fixed it:

The Problem
The original test was expecting a simple "Timeout" error message, but the actual implementation throws a more detailed error: "Timeout loading [url] after [timeout]ms".

The Solution
I made several key changes:

Fixed the timeout test assertion: Changed from expecting just 'Timeout' to using a regex pattern /Timeout loading.*after 100ms/ that matches the actual error message format.

Used a single-source asset: Created a dedicated asset with only one source URL to prevent the test from falling back to a second source and getting a different error.

Proper mock setup: Used new Promise(() => {}) (a promise that never resolves) to simulate a truly hanging request that triggers the timeout mechanism.

Fixed other interfering tests: For tests that were failing due to retry logic interference, I:

Used loaders with maxRetries: 1 to minimize retry attempts
Used single-source assets where appropriate to avoid fallback behavior
This fixed the "should handle HTTP errors" and "should handle audio decoding errors" tests
Key Changes Made
Timeout test: Now properly tests the timeout functionality with the correct error message pattern
HTTP error test: Uses a no-retry loader and single-source asset to test HTTP error handling cleanly
Audio decoding error test: Similar approach to test decoding errors without retry interference
Fallback test: Uses a no-retry loader to cleanly test the fallback mechanism
All 16 tests now pass consistently, including the originally failing timeout test. The tests properly cover all the AssetLoader functionality including timeout handling, error recovery, retry logic, and progress tracking.
